name: Bead Strings
description: Strings of 20 or 100 beads with a colour change every 10 beads. The decade colour change makes the base-10 structure tactile: children feel the group of 10 as a colour boundary. Used for counting, addition within 20/100, and number bonds.
virtual_interaction_notes: Slide beads left/right along a horizontal string. Colour groups of 10 snap together visually. Virtual versions should preserve the tactile 'slide and count' interaction.
agent_prompt: When describing bead strings, emphasise the colour change every 10 beads. For a child working at home, a shoelace threaded with 20 pasta pieces (10 plain, 10 coloured with felt-tip) is a valid substitute. Always say 'slide the beads' rather than 'move the beads' to reinforce the physical action.

name: Counters
description: Small flat circular tokens used for counting, grouping, sharing, and representing quantities. Plain counters are non-proportional (each counter represents one unit regardless of size). The simplest and most versatile concrete manipulative in primary maths.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag-and-drop circles on a workspace. Should support snapping to ten frames, part-whole models, and sorting hoops. Colour should be changeable.
agent_prompt: Counters are the default manipulative when no specific resource is named. If a child is working at home, buttons, coins, dried pasta, or small toys are all valid substitutes. Always specify the quantity needed. Say 'take 12 counters' not 'use some counters'.

name: Two-Colour Counters
description: Counters with different colours on each side (typically red/yellow or red/blue). When flipped, they represent two complementary parts of a whole. Essential for number bonds, subtraction as the inverse of addition, and early algebra (positive/negative).
virtual_interaction_notes: Click to flip between colours. Should support dragging into groups, ten frames, and part-whole models. Running totals of each colour should be visible.
agent_prompt: Two-colour counters are specifically for partitioning and number bonds. Say 'flip the counter to show the other part' when teaching number bonds. At home, coins (heads/tails) or buttons placed face-up/face-down are substitutes. Do not use plain counters when two-colour counters are specified — the colour flip is the pedagogical point.

name: Place Value Counters
description: Counters labelled with their value (1, 10, 100, 1000, 0.1, 0.01). Unlike plain counters, each counter explicitly states its value, making the place value system tangible. Used with a place value mat for addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division with exchange/regrouping.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag counters onto a columnar place value mat. Support automatic regrouping animations: 10 ones-counters exchanged for 1 tens-counter. Decimal counters (0.1, 0.01) essential for Y5-Y6.
agent_prompt: Place value counters replace Dienes blocks from Y4 onward because they can represent any value including decimals. Always use them on a place value mat with column headers. When describing exchange, say '10 ones are worth the same as 1 ten — swap them' rather than 'carry'. At home, write values on small pieces of card or use labelled sticky notes.

name: Interlocking Cubes
description: Small plastic cubes (typically 2cm) that click together to form towers and shapes. Also known as Multilink cubes, Unifix cubes, or linking cubes. Used for counting, comparison, measurement (non-standard units), early multiplication (arrays), pattern work, and 3D shape exploration.
virtual_interaction_notes: Click to connect cubes into towers. Support breaking apart and comparing tower heights. 3D rotation for shape work in later years.
agent_prompt: When describing interlocking cubes, specify the colour and arrangement. Say 'build a tower of 5 red cubes and a tower of 3 blue cubes — which is taller and by how many?' At home, Lego bricks or stacking blocks work as substitutes. Always ask the child to describe the comparison in a sentence.

name: Numicon
description: Flat plastic shapes with regularly spaced holes representing numbers 1-10. The five-structure is built in: numbers 1-5 form a single row; numbers 6-10 use a second row showing '5 and a bit more'. Odd numbers have a protruding peg. Numicon foregrounds the structure of number: odd/even, near-doubles, bonds to 10.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag Numicon plates onto a baseboard. Support overlaying plates to show bonds to 10 and comparing plates side-by-side. The five-row structure must be visually prominent.
agent_prompt: Numicon is specifically for understanding number structure, not for calculation. Use phrases like 'the 7-plate has 5 holes in the top row and 2 in the bottom — it is 5 and 2 more.' When comparing, overlay plates to show 'which is bigger and by how many holes.' At home, drawing Numicon shapes on squared paper (colouring squares) is a valid substitute. Egg boxes cut to size also work.

name: Dienes Blocks (Base-10 Apparatus)
description: Proportional base-10 blocks: unit cubes (ones), ten-sticks (tens), hundred-flats (hundreds), thousand-cubes (thousands). Size directly encodes value — a ten-stick is physically 10 times the length of a unit cube. The foundational manipulative for place value and columnar arithmetic in Y2-Y3.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag blocks onto a place value mat. Support automatic regrouping animation: dragging 10 unit cubes together snaps them into a ten-stick. Breaking a ten-stick apart produces 10 unit cubes. This exchange animation is the key pedagogical moment.
agent_prompt: Dienes blocks are the primary manipulative for understanding place value and columnar methods in Y2-Y3. Always use them on a place value mat with clear column headers. When teaching exchange, physically (or virtually) swap 10 ones for 1 ten — say 'these 10 ones are worth the same as this 1 ten.' At home, bundles of 10 straws (tens) and individual straws (ones) are the best substitute. Lollipop sticks bundled with elastic bands also work.

name: Cuisenaire Rods
description: Coloured rods of lengths 1-10 (white=1, red=2, light green=3, ... orange=10). Unlike Dienes blocks, Cuisenaire rods foreground proportional relationships between ANY two numbers, not just base-10. Essential for fraction equivalence, ratio, and algebraic thinking.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag rods end-to-end for comparison and combination. Support lining up rods to show equivalence (e.g. 2 light greens = 1 dark green). Colour coding must match the standard Cuisenaire colour scheme.
agent_prompt: Cuisenaire rods are for relationships and comparison, not for counting. Never label the rods with numbers initially — let the child discover which rod is worth what by comparing. Say 'if the orange rod is worth 10, what is the yellow rod worth?' At home, cut strips of coloured card to the correct proportional lengths (1cm per unit). Paper strip Cuisenaire is a well-known primary substitute.

name: Ten Frames
description: A 2x5 grid frame into which counters or objects are placed. Foregrounds the five-structure and bonds to 10: a frame with 7 counters immediately shows 3 empty spaces (bond to 10). Double ten frames (two side-by-side) extend to 20.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag counters into the 2x5 grid. Filled and empty cells should be visually distinct. Support double ten frames by placing two side-by-side. Clear/reset functionality essential.
agent_prompt: Ten frames teach bonds to 10 through visual structure. Always fill from top-left, row by row. Say 'how many counters are there? How many empty spaces? So 7 and 3 make 10.' At home, draw a 2x5 grid on paper and use coins, buttons, or dried pasta as counters. Egg cartons cut to 2x5 also work perfectly.

name: Fraction Tiles and Circles
description: Flat tiles or circular sectors representing unit fractions (1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/5, 1/6, 1/8, 1/10, 1/12). Tiles are rectangular strips that line up for comparison; circles are pie-shaped sectors that fit together to make wholes. Essential for fraction equivalence, comparison, and addition/subtraction of fractions.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag fraction pieces onto a fraction wall template or into a circle outline. Support overlaying pieces to show equivalence (e.g. 2/6 = 1/3). Snapping to the whole-circle outline for fractions that make 1.
agent_prompt: Fraction tiles are for comparing and combining fractions physically. Always start with the whole tile visible — say 'this is one whole. How many thirds fit inside it?' At home, fold strips of paper into equal parts (fold in half for halves, thirds by folding into three). Paper plate fractions (cutting a plate into equal sectors) are an excellent home substitute for fraction circles.

name: Fraction Wall
description: A physical or printed wall chart showing a whole divided into halves, thirds, quarters, fifths, sixths, eighths, tenths, and twelfths as horizontal bars. The bars are aligned vertically so equivalent fractions sit at the same horizontal position. A reference tool rather than a hands-on manipulative — children look at it, point to it, and trace equivalences.
virtual_interaction_notes: Interactive version where children can highlight and shade bars. Clicking two fractions should show whether they are equivalent by highlighting the shared vertical boundary.
agent_prompt: A fraction wall is a reference tool, not a hands-on manipulative. Use it for equivalence ('look at the wall — which fractions line up with 1/2?') and comparison ('which is bigger, 1/3 or 1/4? Look at the wall to check'). At home, print a fraction wall from any primary maths resource site. Children can also make their own by folding strips of paper into different numbers of equal parts and gluing them onto card.

name: Arrow Cards (Place Value Cards)
description: Overlapping cards showing ones (1-9), tens (10-90), hundreds (100-900), and thousands (1000-9000). Each card has an arrow point on the right side. When overlaid, the arrows align and the combined card shows the full number. Children can physically partition a number by pulling the cards apart.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag-and-overlap cards to build numbers. Pulling cards apart should animate the partitioning. Support up to millions for Y6.
agent_prompt: Arrow cards teach partitioning by physical overlay. Say 'build the number 347 — which cards do you need?' (300, 40, 7). Then 'pull the cards apart — what is the number made of?' At home, write numbers on strips of card and cut them so they can be overlaid. The arrow shape is not essential — overlapping strips work if the child understands the overlay principle.

name: Place Value Mat
description: A mat with clearly labelled columns for each place value position (ones, tens, hundreds, etc.). Not a manipulative itself but the essential work surface for Dienes blocks and place value counters. The column headings make the positional value system explicit.
virtual_interaction_notes: Always present as the drop target for Dienes blocks or place value counters. Column headers should be clearly visible. Support up to 7 columns (millions) for Y6.
agent_prompt: A place value mat is always used WITH Dienes blocks or place value counters, never on its own. Say 'put the tens in the tens column and the ones in the ones column.' At home, draw columns on a whiteboard or large piece of paper with column headers labelled T, O or H, T, O as appropriate for the year group.

name: Coins and Notes
description: Real or plastic UK coins (1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p, 50p, 1 pound, 2 pound) and notes (5 pound, 10 pound, 20 pound). Used for money work, counting in multiples, place value (10p = 10 x 1p), and real-world contexts. Non-proportional: a 10p coin is not 10 times the size of a 1p coin.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag-and-drop coins with realistic UK designs. Support totalling (running total display), exchanging (10 x 1p for 1 x 10p), and arranging in value order.
agent_prompt: When using coins, always specify the denominations available. Say 'using only 10p and 1p coins, make 47p' not 'use coins to make 47p.' Coins are non-proportional — a 10p coin is not bigger than a 5p coin. This is a key teaching point: unlike Dienes blocks, the size does not tell you the value. At home, real coins are ideal. If unavailable, print coin images from a maths resource site.

name: Geared Demonstration Clock
description: A clock face with geared hands so that when the minute hand moves, the hour hand moves proportionally. Individual student clocks allow hands-on practice. Essential for teaching time: the proportional gearing makes the relationship between minutes and hours visible.
virtual_interaction_notes: Interactive clock face with geared hands. Child drags the minute hand and the hour hand follows proportionally. Support both 12-hour and 24-hour faces. Display digital time alongside analogue.
agent_prompt: Always start with the minute hand and let the child observe the hour hand following. Say 'move the minute hand all the way round — what happened to the hour hand?' (it moved from one number to the next). At home, make a paper plate clock with a split pin. The gearing is lost but the face reading practice is preserved.

name: Rulers and Metre Sticks
description: Standard rulers (30cm) and metre sticks (100cm) for measuring length. Rulers with both centimetre and millimetre gradations. The ruler is both a measuring tool and a concrete number line — reading a ruler is reading a scale, which connects to number line fluency.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag a virtual ruler alongside objects to measure. Support zooming to read mm gradations. The connection between ruler reading and number line reading should be made explicit.
agent_prompt: When teaching measurement, always check that the child starts from 0, not from the end of the ruler. Common error: starting from 1 or from the edge of the ruler where there is no 0 mark. Say 'line up the 0 on your ruler with the start of the object.' At home, any ruler will do — the specific brand does not matter. If no ruler is available, a strip of paper marked in centimetres works.

name: Balance Scales
description: A pan balance with two pans for comparing masses. Foregrounds the equals-sign concept: both sides must balance. Used for comparing masses, ordering objects by weight, and introducing the concept of equality in equations.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag objects or standard weights onto pans. The balance should tilt proportionally. Support both comparison (heavier/lighter) and measurement (using standard weights).
agent_prompt: Balance scales teach equality. Say 'what can you add to this side to make it balance?' This is the foundation for understanding the equals sign as 'the same as' rather than 'the answer is.' At home, a coat hanger with plastic bags on each end works as a simple balance. Or compare objects by hand: hold one in each hand and feel which is heavier.

name: Measuring Jugs and Containers
description: Transparent jugs and cylinders with graduated scales for measuring capacity and volume in millilitres and litres. The scale-reading skill connects directly to number line reading. Essential for measurement and statistics (reading scales) across KS1-KS2.
virtual_interaction_notes: Pour virtual liquid into a graduated container. The liquid level should correspond to the scale markings. Support different scale intervals (marked in 10ml, 50ml, 100ml).
agent_prompt: Measuring jugs teach scale reading. Say 'what number is the water level closest to?' and 'what are the small marks between the big numbers worth?' At home, any measuring jug from the kitchen works. Focus on reading the scale at eye level — children commonly read from above, which gives an incorrect reading.

name: Geoboards
description: A board with pegs arranged in a square grid (typically 5x5). Elastic bands are stretched between pegs to create 2D shapes. Used for exploring properties of shapes, perimeter, area, angles, and symmetry. The grid structure makes shape properties measurable.
virtual_interaction_notes: Click pegs and drag elastic bands between them. Support multiple bands on the same board for comparing shapes. Area counting by grid squares should be supported.
agent_prompt: Geoboards are for exploring shape properties through construction. Say 'make a rectangle that is 3 pegs wide and 2 pegs tall — how many squares are inside it?' At home, a printed dot grid (5x5 dots on paper) with a pencil and ruler works for the same activities. Or use a corkboard with drawing pins and elastic bands.

name: 3D Shape Models
description: Solid plastic or wooden models of 3D shapes: cubes, cuboids, cylinders, spheres, cones, pyramids, triangular prisms, and (from Y5) regular polyhedra. Used for identifying faces, edges, vertices, and exploring nets and cross-sections.
virtual_interaction_notes: 3D shapes that can be rotated, unfolded into nets, and sliced to show cross-sections. VR/AR environments offer significant advantages over screen-based 2D representations for 3D shape work.
agent_prompt: When teaching 3D shapes, always ask the child to pick up the shape and describe what they feel. Say 'how many flat faces can you feel? Run your finger along an edge. How many edges?' At home, household objects are the best 3D shapes: tins (cylinders), boxes (cuboids), balls (spheres), Toblerone boxes (triangular prisms), ice cream cones (cones).

name: Pattern Blocks
description: Flat geometric tiles in standard shapes and colours: yellow hexagons, red trapezoids, blue rhombuses (wide), green triangles, orange squares, tan rhombuses (narrow). The shapes tessellate and relate to each other proportionally (6 green triangles = 1 yellow hexagon). Used for shape recognition, symmetry, fractions, and pattern work.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag and rotate tiles on a flat workspace. Support snapping edges together. Show how tiles combine to fill the hexagon outline for fraction work.
agent_prompt: Pattern blocks are for shape relationships and tessellation. Say 'how many green triangles fill the yellow hexagon?' (6) and 'how many red trapezoids fill it?' (2). This is fraction work: 1 triangle = 1/6 of the hexagon. At home, print and cut pattern block shapes from a template. The standard colours and proportions matter for fraction equivalence work.

name: Sorting Hoops
description: Large coloured hoops (typically 3-4) placed on the floor or table for sorting objects by criteria. When overlapped, they create Venn diagram regions for classifying objects that share properties. A concrete introduction to set theory and data handling.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag hoops onto a workspace and label them. Drag objects into regions. Overlapping regions should be visually distinct. Support 2-circle and 3-circle Venn configurations.
agent_prompt: Sorting hoops are for classifying. Say 'put all the red shapes in this hoop and all the triangles in this hoop. What goes in the middle where the hoops overlap?' (red triangles). At home, use skipping ropes or string in circles on the floor.

name: Protractor
description: A semicircular tool for measuring and drawing angles in degrees. Standard 180-degree protractors with inner and outer scales. Essential from Y5 for measuring angles and classifying them as acute, obtuse, right, or reflex.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag and rotate a virtual protractor over angles on screen. The angle measurement should display dynamically as the protractor is positioned. Support both measuring and drawing angles.
agent_prompt: The most common error with protractors is reading the wrong scale (inner vs outer). Teach the check: 'does your angle look like it is less than 90 or more than 90? Now check your reading matches that.' Always place the protractor with the centre point on the vertex and the baseline along one arm. At home, protractors are inexpensive and widely available. There is no good home substitute — angle measurement requires the tool.

name: Pair of Compasses
description: A drawing compass for constructing circles and arcs. Used from Y5 for circle construction and from Y6 for constructing triangles, perpendicular bisectors, and angle bisectors. A precision tool that requires fine motor control.
virtual_interaction_notes: Click to set centre point, drag to set radius, draw arc or full circle. Support construction sequences (e.g. marking two arcs from different centres for perpendicular bisectors).
agent_prompt: Compass work requires practice with the physical tool. Say 'push the point firmly into the paper. Hold the top of the compass between finger and thumb. Swing the pencil end around without wobbling.' Common error: the point slipping, making an oval. At home, a compass from any stationery set works. If unavailable, a pencil tied to string with a pin is a rough substitute for drawing circles.

name: Mirrors (Mira Mirrors)
description: Flat safety mirrors placed on shapes or patterns to explore lines of symmetry. Mira mirrors (transparent red plastic) are specifically designed for maths: the child can see through the mirror to check whether the reflection matches the original. Used for symmetry and reflection in geometry.
virtual_interaction_notes: Place a virtual mirror line on a shape. One side of the mirror line shows the actual shape; the other side shows the reflection. Support dragging the mirror line to test different symmetry lines.
agent_prompt: Place the mirror on a dotted line and ask 'does the reflected shape look the same as the original?' If yes, it is a line of symmetry. At home, any small flat mirror works. Hold it upright on the shape and look at the reflection. The advantage of a Mira mirror is that you can see through it — but a regular mirror is fine for basic symmetry work.

name: Thermometers
description: Liquid-in-glass or digital thermometers for measuring temperature in degrees Celsius. A vertical number line in physical form. Used for measurement, reading scales, and (critically) for introducing negative numbers — temperature is the most natural context for numbers below zero.
virtual_interaction_notes: Interactive thermometer with a draggable mercury level. Must show negative numbers below the 0 mark. Support both Celsius and Fahrenheit for cross-curricular science work.
agent_prompt: Thermometers are a vertical number line. Say 'what temperature is it now? What would happen if it got 5 degrees colder?' This naturally introduces negative numbers: 'it is 3 degrees — if it gets 5 degrees colder, where does the red line go? Below zero!' At home, check the weather app or put a real thermometer outside. The outdoor thermometer reading activity is a classic Y3-Y4 practical maths task.

name: Counting Stick
description: A metre-long stick divided into 10 equal sections by coloured bands. The teacher holds it horizontally and points to sections while the class counts. A whole-class teaching tool for oral skip counting, number sequences, fractions (each section = 1/10), and establishing number line concepts. Not a hands-on student manipulative — a teacher-led visualisation aid.
virtual_interaction_notes: A horizontal bar divided into 10 equal sections. Tap/click sections to label them with numbers. Support relabelling for different counting sequences (e.g. 0-100 in 10s, 0-1 in 0.1s, 0-1000 in 100s).
agent_prompt: The counting stick is a teacher-led tool for oral rehearsal. Point to each section in turn and say the count. Then point randomly and ask 'what number is here?' Crucially, turn the stick around (right to left) for counting backwards. Label the ends first, then the middle, then fill in the rest — this builds estimation. At home, draw a horizontal bar divided into 10 on a whiteboard or paper.

name: Numeral Cards and Digit Cards
description: Individual cards showing digits (0-9) or numerals (1-20, 1-100). Used for number recognition, ordering, sequencing, matching to quantities, and card games for fluency practice. Numeral cards show complete numbers; digit cards show single digits for building multi-digit numbers.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag cards to reorder. Support shuffling, revealing one at a time, and placing in sequence. Timer mode for fluency games.
agent_prompt: Numeral cards are for recognition and ordering. Say 'put these numbers in order from smallest to biggest' or 'I will show you a card — read the number as fast as you can.' At home, write numbers on pieces of card or use a deck of playing cards (remove face cards for number work).

name: Algebra Tiles
description: Rectangular and square tiles representing algebraic terms: small unit squares (1), rectangular bars (x), and large squares (x-squared). Two-coloured (one side positive, flip for negative). Used from KS3 for expanding brackets, factorising, and solving equations. The area model made physical.
virtual_interaction_notes: Drag tiles onto a workspace. Support building area models for expanding brackets. Flip tiles for negative terms. Group tiles for collecting like terms. The virtual version is especially important as many secondary schools do not have physical algebra tile sets.
agent_prompt: Algebra tiles make abstract algebra concrete. For expanding 3(x + 2): build 3 rows, each row containing 1 x-bar and 2 unit squares. The total area = 3 x-bars + 6 unit squares = 3x + 6. Say 'the rectangle has width 3 and length (x + 2). What is the total area?' At home, cut paper strips and squares to scale. Many free virtual algebra tile apps are available online.

name: Dice and Spinners
description: Standard 6-sided dice (dot and numeral), blank dice for custom faces, 10-sided dice (0-9), and spinners with customisable sections. Used for probability, mental arithmetic games, random number generation, and data collection activities.
virtual_interaction_notes: Click to roll with realistic animation. Support standard 6-sided, 10-sided, and custom-face dice. Spinner with adjustable equal/unequal sections for probability work.
agent_prompt: Dice are for probability and fluency games. For probability: 'if you roll a dice, what are the possible outcomes? Which numbers are you most/least likely to roll?' For fluency: 'roll two dice and multiply the numbers together as fast as you can.' At home, any board game dice works. For spinners, draw a circle on card, divide into sections, and spin a paperclip on a pencil point.
